title: R45119
content: In October 2017, the U.S. EPA proposed repealing the CPP, a rule finalized in 2015 to limit CO2 emissions from fossil-fuel-fired power plants. The CPP has faced legal challenges and has not been implemented. Disagreements revolve around legal justification, design, and cost-benefit analysis. The rule set national CO2 emission rates for power plants under the Clean Air Act Section 111(d). States were given compliance options. The EPA proposed repealing the CPP, a rule to limit CO2 emissions from power plants. States had options to comply through rate-based or mass-based approaches, providing flexibility in achieving emission goals. EPA's regulatory analysis in 2015 projected a 32% reduction in CO2 emissions from the power sector. The EPA proposed repealing the CPP, a rule to limit CO2 emissions from power plants, citing a change in interpretation of its authority under the Clean Air Act. The repeal marks a significant shift from the previous Administration's stance on the issue. EPA projected a 32% reduction in CO2 emissions from the power sector by 2030 under the CPP. The EPA estimated the benefits and costs of the proposed repeal of the CPP, which is considered an economically significant regulatory action. The benefit-cost analysis of the repeal reveals methodological changes from the 2015 analysis, potentially impacting how EPA estimates benefits and costs of other regulations. Members of Congress may be interested in understanding these changes and how they differ from the previous analysis. The EPA conducted a benefit-cost analysis of the proposed repeal of the CPP, revealing methodological changes from the 2015 analysis. Senators requested more information on these changes, which could impact how federal agencies account for climate and human health benefits in future regulations. The EPA conducted a benefit-cost analysis of the proposed repeal of the CPP, highlighting methodological changes from the 2015 analysis. The report compares the conclusions of EPA's 2015 and 2017 benefit-cost analyses, focusing on climate benefits, human health co-benefits, and energy savings impact. For more details on EPA's rationale for the repeal, refer to CRS Report R44992, and for legal aspects, see CRS Legal Sidebar LSB10016. The EPA prepares benefit-cost analyses for significant regulatory actions, such as the Clean Power Plan, in accordance with Executive Order 12866. This order directs federal agencies to examine the benefits and costs of significant regulatory actions to ensure that the benefits justify the costs. The EPA follows Executive Order 12866 to analyze the benefits and costs of significant regulatory actions, which are defined as rules with a $100 million annual impact on the economy or that create inconsistencies with other agency actions, alter budget impacts, or raise novel legal or policy issues. OMB Circular A-4 provides guidance on developing a good regulatory analysis. The OMB Circular A-4 defines a good regulatory analysis as explicitly stating the need for the proposed action, analyzing alternative approaches, and assessing benefits and costs. It aims to standardize measurement and reporting of economically significant regulatory actions across federal agencies, informing whether benefits justify costs. Monetized benefits do not need to outweigh costs, as quantified estimates may not capture all anticipated impacts. The EPA prepared a regulatory analysis for the CPP in 2015, following E.O. 12866 and Circular A-4 guidelines to quantify benefits and costs of economically significant regulations. State-specific emission rate goals were calculated for the rate-based scenario. EPA calculated state-specific emission rate goals and emission goals for the rate-based and mass-based scenarios of the CPP. The analysis, done using the Integrated Planning Model, estimated emission reductions and compliance costs, emphasizing the illustrative nature of the scenarios. Compliance costs were reported as the additional cost of complying with the CPP in a given year. The EPA estimated compliance costs for the Clean Power Plan (CPP) based on changes in capital investment, operating pollution controls, fuel shifts, and energy efficiency measures. The plan aimed to reduce CO2 and non-GHG emissions, with costs including monitoring and reporting. The EPA used the IPM model to project CO2 reductions and applied the social cost of carbon (SCC) to assess the economic value of climate benefits. The EPA estimated the economic value of climate benefits by applying the social cost of carbon (SCC) to reductions in CO2 emissions. They also quantified human health benefits from reductions in non-GHG emissions like SO2 and NOx, monetizing the benefits of reduced exposure to PM and ozone. EPA monetized human health benefits from reduced exposure to PM and ozone using a "benefit-per-ton" approach. The estimates represented the value of reductions in premature deaths and illnesses associated with exposure to PM and ozone, with PM health effects accounting for most of the monetized health co-benefits estimates. The EPA estimated that reductions in SO2 emissions accounted for 80-85% of the health co-benefits from PM exposure in 2030. Ozone health effects made up a smaller share, around 6-12%. The EPA revised estimates of the Social Cost of Carbon (SCC) to value climate benefits of CO2 reductions. SCC values were calculated using models to estimate economic impacts of emissions changes. In 2015, EPA estimated climate benefits of the CPP using SCC values developed by an interagency working group (IWG), which were later withdrawn by the Trump Administration in 2017. The Trump Administration withdrew the IWG's SCC estimates in 2017 as part of E.O. 13783, directing agencies to use discount rates of 3% and 7% for valuing climate change impacts in regulatory analysis. EPA developed new SCC values based on this directive. EPA developed new interim SCC values based on E.O. 13783, using models and assumptions similar to the IWG but adjusting for domestic scope and discount rates. The domestic SCC estimates from three models are $7 and $1 per metric ton of CO2 emissions in 2030 at 3% discount rates. OMB Circular A-4 discusses discount rate selection for benefit-cost analysis, recommending rates of 3% and 7%. OMB Circular A-4 recommends discount rates of 3% and 7% for benefit-cost analysis based on scenarios affecting consumer spending or private capital. The 3% rate, known as the "consumption rate," reflects the average saver's discount rate for future consumption, while the 7% rate represents the opportunity cost of capital. Discounting is the final step in calculating the Social Cost of Carbon (SCC). Discounting in the Social Cost of Carbon (SCC) calculation allows for comparisons of economic impacts occurring at different times. Selecting a discount rate for SCC is challenging due to the intergenerational aspect of climate change, as it involves valuing impacts on future generations without their input. The selection of a discount rate for the Social Cost of Carbon (SCC) calculation is crucial for valuing climate change impacts on future generations. Higher discount rates lead to lower present values, while lower discount rates result in higher present values. The sensitivity of SCC estimates to discount rate selection highlights the ethical implications of comparing benefits and costs across generations, as acknowledged in OMB Circular A-4. EPA applied a threshold to forgone health co-benefits in benefit-cost comparisons, counting only those exceeding a defined threshold for ambient PM levels. EPA used thresholds to calculate PM mortality impacts, assuming no deaths below certain levels. One threshold was based on the federal air quality standard for PM, while the second was based on the "lowest measured level" from two long-term studies. EPA diverged from past practice by using these thresholds in benefit-cost comparisons.
